DOCNAME: CASE OF LE COMPTE, VAN LEUVEN AND DE MEYERE v. BELGIUM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;No violation of Art. 11;Just satisfaction reserved
TEXT: CARDINAL . Dr. PERSON , a NORP national born in DATE and resident at ORG , is a medical practitioner .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG of the Ordre des médecins ( ORG ) , which sits in GPE , ordered that Dr. PERSON right to practise medicine be suspended for DATE . The ground was that he had given to a NORP newspaper an interview considered by the ORG to amount to publicity incompatible with the dignity and reputation of the profession . The applicant lodged an objection ( opposition ) against this decision , which had been given in absentia , but it was confirmed by ORG on DATE , the applicant again having failed to appear .

Dr. PERSON thereupon referred the matter firstly to ORG , which , on DATE , held his appeal to be inadmissible , and secondly to ORG , on DATE , the latter declared his appeal on a point of law inadmissible , on the ground that it had been filed without the assistance of a lawyer entitled to practise before that ORG .

The order suspending Dr. PERSON right to practise became effective on DATE but he did not comply with it . For this reason , on DATE , the NORP criminal court ( tribunal correctionnel ) sentenced him , pursuant to LAW no . CARDINAL of DATE on ORG , to imprisonment and a fine .
This decision was confirmed on DATE by ORG ; a appeal by Dr. PERSON on a point of law was dismissed by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . Concurrently with the foregoing proceedings , which are not in issue in the present case ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , further proceedings were in progress . In fact , on DATE ORG of the Ordre des médecins had , by a decision rendered in absentia , ordered another suspension , for DATE , of the applicant ’s right to practise : the ORG stated that he had publicised in the press the above - mentioned decisions of the disciplinary organs of the ORG and his criticisms of those organs , such conduct constituting contempt of the ORG .

CARDINAL . Dr. PERSON had appealed to ORG which had confirmed this decision although without upholding the allegation of contempt . He had then referred the matter to ORG , where he relied on the same grounds .

He contended in the first place that compulsory membership of ORG , without which no one may practise medicine and subjection to the jurisdiction of its disciplinary organs were contrary to the principle of freedom of association , which is guaranteed by LAW ( LAW ) of the Convention .
The ORG rejected this plea in the following terms :

" ... compulsory entry on the register of an ordre which , like the Ordre des médecins , is a public - law institution having the function of ensuring the observance of the medical profession ’s rules of professional conduct and the maintenance of the reputation , standards of discretion , probity and dignity of its members can not be regarded as incompatible with freedom of association , as guaranteed by LAW ; ... the appellant does not allege that the rule which he is challenging goes beyond the bounds of the restrictions authorised by LAW . CARDINAL ( LAW ) of the LAW , for example for the protection of health . "

The applicant also alleged a violation of ORG CARDINAL of the LAW : the first provides that the courts of law shall have exclusive jurisdiction to determine disputes over civil rights and the second prohibits the establishment of extraordinary tribunals for the purpose of resolving such disputes . He pointed out that the decision complained of had nonetheless been taken by a disciplinary organ , set up by LAW no . DATE , and that it had given a ruling on a civil right , namely the right to practise medicine .

ORG replied that " disciplinary proceedings and the imposition of disciplinary sanctions are , in principle , unrelated to the disputes over which exclusive jurisdiction is reserved to the courts of law by LAW " . The ORG added that , since ORG did not have jurisdiction to determine such disputes , " they are not extraordinary tribunals whose establishment is prohibited by LAW " . Finally , the ORG observed that section CARDINAL par . CARDINAL ( a ) of the LAW of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) empowered the Crown " to reform and adapt the legislation governing the practice of the various branches of medicine " and that " the legislature was referring , inter alia , to LAW DATE establishing the ORG , which Act conferred disciplinary powers on ORG " .

Lastly , Dr. PERSON alleged that there had been a violation of LAW . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) of the Convention . He argued that the decision complained of had been given without any public inquiry and by a tribunal composed of medical practitioners , which could not be regarded as impartial since the kind of conduct of which he was accused might harm his colleagues .
ORG confined itself to pointing out that LAW . CARDINAL ( article DATE ) did not apply to disciplinary proceedings .
Accordingly , by judgment of CARDINAL DATE , the appeal was dismissed .

CARDINAL . Dr. PERSON did not comply with the order suspending his right to practise medicine , which became final following ORG judgment . On that account he was sentenced by the PERSON criminal court on DATE and DATE to terms of imprisonment and fines . He lodged an appeal against the first decision and an objection against the second , which had been rendered in absentia .

CARDINAL . Since that time , a number of further proceedings have been instituted , both disciplinary , for the publicity given by the applicant to his dispute with the ORG , and criminal , for his refusal to comply with the measures imposed by its ORG .

CARDINAL of the disciplinary proceedings resulted in Dr. PERSON being struck off the register of the ORG with effect from DATE . In this connection he lodged a further application ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) with the Commission on DATE ; that application , which the ORG declared admissible on DATE , is not relevant for the examination of the present case .
The criminal proceedings , at first instance , led to prison sentences and to fines .
CARDINAL . Dr. PERSON and Dr. PERSON are medical practitioners , born in DATE and DATE , respectively . Both of them reside at ORG and are NORP nationals .

CARDINAL . On DATE , CARDINAL medical practitioners practising in and around ORG filed a complaint to the effect that these CARDINAL applicants had committed breaches of the rules of professional conduct ; it was alleged , in particular , that they had systematically limited their fees to the amounts reimbursed by ORG , even when on emergency duty , and had distributed without charge to private houses a DATE magazine called ORG in which general practitioners were held up to ridicule . On DATE , the applicants were heard by ORG . They admitted that they had limited the fees charged to their own clients but not the fees charged when they were on emergency duty . In addition , they pointed out that they were not the publishers of ORG and they denied that they had lampooned their colleagues in its pages .

CARDINAL . On DATE , another medical practitioner lodged a further complaint against the applicants ; he alleged that , DATE after their appearance before ORG , they had put up in the waiting rooms of the ORG medical centre a notice informing the public of the first complaint and the reasons therefore . On DATE , ORG heard the applicants in connection with the second complaint . They declared that they were entitled to provide the public with information about the situation , especially as it was already a matter of common knowledge .
CARDINAL . ORG of the Ordre des médecins , which sits in GPE , summoned Dr. PERSON and Dr. PERSON to answer several allegations .

On DATE , it directed that their right to practise medicine be suspended for DATE for having charged fees limited to the amounts reimbursed by ORG , for having contributed to the magazine Gezond and for having made therein public utterances judged offensive to their colleagues . In addition , Dr. PERSON was reprimanded for his behaviour when appearing before ORG on DATE . These various decisions were based on Articles CARDINAL par . CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW no . CARDINAL .

ORG considered , on the other hand , that the posting in the waiting rooms of the medical centre of a notice judged contrary to the rules of professional conduct did not warrant a disciplinary sanction , bearing in mind that the notice had been removed following a request from the ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicants appealed to ORG .

On DATE , the latter declared the appeal admissible and upheld ORG decision insofar as it had found established the allegations relating to the charging of fees limited to the amounts reimbursed by ORG and the contribution to the magazine Gezond . For the rest , ORG set aside the decision challenged and , after taking into account the complaint regarding the notice in the waiting rooms and joining it with the CARDINAL other complaints , directed that the right of Dr. PERSON and Dr. PERSON to practise medicine be suspended for DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG ruled against the applicants , who had appealed on a point of law .

The ORG rejected the ground of appeal based on breach of LAW ( LAW ) of the Convention ; it considered that the functions of the Ordre des médecins " are by no means unrelated to the protection of health and that compulsory entry ... on the register of an Ordre of this kind does not exceed the restrictions on freedom of association which are necessary for the protection of health " .

The ORG in addition declared inadmissible , for want of legal interest , the ground of appeal to the effect that the limitation of fees to the amounts reimbursed by ORG was in conformity with both the law and the rules of professional conduct for medical practitioners ; the ORG found that the suspension had in fact also been imposed as a sanction for other disciplinary offences .

CARDINAL . The ordre des médecins , which was established by an Act of DATE , was re - organised by LAW no . CARDINAL of DATE . This Decree was made under LAW of DATE " investing the King with certain powers with a view to ensuring economic revival , acceleration of regional reconversion and a stable , balanced budget " . The LAW enabled the ORG , acting by ORG , to take " all appropriate steps ... to further the quality and ensure satisfactory provision of health care through reform and adaptation of the legislation governing the practice of the various branches of medicine " ( section CARDINAL par . CARDINAL ( a ) ) ; it specified that such Decrees could " repeal supplement , amend or replace existing legal provisions " ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . LAW no . CARDINAL provides that " the ORG shall include all physicians , surgeons and obstetricians who are permanently resident in GPE and entered on the register of ORG where they have their permanent residence " and that " in order to practise medicine in GPE , every medical practitioner " - whether NORP or foreign - " must be entered on the register of the Ordre " .
Military doctors , however , are only obliged to be entered on the register if they practise outside their military duties .

CARDINAL . Alongside the Ordre des médecins , there exist in GPE private associations formed to protect the professional interests of medical practitioners . The most important of these associations are consulted and invited to take part in collective negotiations when the Government are considering the adoption of decisions affecting those interests , to propose candidates for nomination as members of certain organs and to appoint their representatives on others , and to take various measures themselves .
CARDINAL . The Ordre des médecins " shall enjoy civil personality in public law " ( LAW paragraph , of LAW no . CARDINAL ) . It comprises CARDINAL kinds of organs , namely ORG and ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG ( of which there are CARDINAL ) consist of a number , which is always even and is fixed by the ORG , of members and substitute members who are medical practitioners of NORP nationality elected for DATE by doctors entered on the register of the ORG . There are also an assessor and a substitute assessor who are judges of first instance courts appointed for DATE by the ORG ; the assessor has a consultative status ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL par . CARDINAL of LAW no . CARDINAL ) .
The ORG ’s functions are defined by LAW no . CARDINAL in the following terms :

" CARDINAL to keep the register of the Ordre . They may refuse or defer entry on the register if the person applying has been guilty either of an act of such seriousness as would cause the name of a member of the Ordre to be struck off the register or of serious misconduct damaging the reputation or dignity of the profession .

If the medical commission ... has decided and notified the ORG that a medical practitioner no longer fulfils the conditions required for practising medicine or that it is necessary , for reasons of physical or mental disability , to place a restriction on the practise by him of medicine , the relevant ORG shall , in the first case , remove the practitioner ’s name from the register and , in the second case , make the maintenance of his name thereon subject to observance of the restriction ordered .
A practitioner ’s name may also be removed from the register at his own request .
Reasons must be given for any decision refusing or deferring entry on the register , removing a practitioner ’s name therefrom or making its maintenance thereon subject to restrictive conditions ;

CARDINAL to ensure observance of the rules of professional conduct for medical practitioners and the upholding of the reputation , standards of discretion , probity and dignity of the members of the Ordre . They shall to this end be responsible for disciplining misconduct committed by their registered members in or in connection with the practice of the profession and serious misconduct committed outside the realm of professional activity , whenever such misconduct is liable to damage the reputation or dignity of the profession ;
CARDINAL to give , of their own motion or on request , the members of the ORG advice on matters of professional conduct ... ; such advice shall be submitted to ORG for approval ... ;
CARDINAL to notify the relevant authorities of any acts involving illegal practice of medicine of which the ORG have knowledge ;
CARDINAL to act , at the joint request of those concerned , as final arbitrator in disputes regarding the fees claimed by a medical practitioner from his client ... ;
CARDINAL to reply to all requests for advice emanating from courts of law in connection with disputes as to fees ;
CARDINAL to settle the DATE subscription ... including the amount fixed by ORG for each registered member . "

CARDINAL . The Provincial councils are distinct from the medical commissions which have been set up , outside the ORG , in each GPE and are composed in addition to medical and pharmaceutical practitioners of members of the paramedical professions and of officials of ORG ( Article CARDINAL of LAW no . CARDINAL ) . These commissions have CARDINAL functions . The first is general and consists of " proposing to the authorities any measures designed to make a contribution to public health " and of " ensuring that practitioners ... ( and ) members of the paramedical professions collaborate effectively in the implementation of the measures laid down by the authorities for the purpose of preventing or combating diseases subject to quarantine or communicable diseases " . The second , specific function comprises various responsibilities : " checking and ... approving practitioners’ diplomas " ; " withdrawing approval or making its continuance in force subject to the acceptance by the person concerned of ( certain ) restrictions " ; " ensuring that the practice of medicine ( is conducted ) in accordance with the laws and regulations " ; " detecting and ... reporting to the prosecuting authority cases of illegal practice " ; assessing the demand for emergency services and supervising their operation ; " informing interested parties , whether acting in public or private capacity , of decisions taken " as regards a practitioner ’s exercise of his profession ; " advising the organs of the ORG concerned of allegations of professional misconduct against practitioners " ; " supervising public sales where medicines are involved " ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG - one of which uses the NORP and the other the NORP language - have their seat " in the LOC area " . They are each composed of CARDINAL medical practitioners of NORP nationality ( CARDINAL members and CARDINAL substitute members ) elected for DATE by ORG from among persons other than their own members , and CARDINAL ORG judges ( CARDINAL members and CARDINAL substitute members ) appointed by the ORG for the same length of time . From among these judges , the ORG designates the Chairman , who has a casting vote , and the member who is to act as rapporteur ( LAW . CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Royal Decree no . CARDINAL ) .

ORG hear appeals from decisions given by ORG on matters of registration or discipline . They deal , as the body of first and final instance , with claims concerning the regularity of elections to ORG , ORG and ORG . They also decide cases on which ORG have not given a ruling within the prescribed time - limit . Finally , they settle any dispute between ORG regarding a practitioner ’s place of permanent residence ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG comprises CARDINAL persons ( QUANTITY members and CARDINAL substitute members ) of NORP nationality who are respectively elected by each of ORG from among medical practitioners entered on its register , and QUANTITY persons ( QUANTITY members and CARDINAL substitute members ) appointed by the ORG from among medical practitioners nominated in lists of CARDINAL candidates by the medical faculties in the country . ORG is presided over by a judge of ORG chosen by the ORG and consists of CARDINAL sections - CARDINAL LANGUAGE - speaking , the other NORP - speaking - each of which elects from among its number a Vice - President ( LAW ) .

ORG formulates " those general principles and those rules concerning the morality , reputation , standards of discretion , probity and devotion to duty essential for practice of the profession which constitute the code of professional conduct for medical practitioners " ; these principles and rules may be made compulsory by ORG ( a draft code failed to receive ORG approval ) . It keeps up to date a list of those disciplinary decisions given by ORG which are no longer open to appeal . It gives reasoned opinions " on general matters , on problems of principle and on the rules of professional conduct " . It settles the amount of the subscription medical practitioners are asked to pay to the ORG . More generally , it takes " all steps necessary for the achievement of the aims of ORG ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . In the procedure relating to disciplinary and registration matters , which is primarily governed by LAW of DATE " regulating the organisation and working of ORG , the contending parties are always heard . There may be CARDINAL stages : a ruling at first instance by ORG , a ruling at final instance by ORG and a review by ORG of the legality of the decisions and the observance of formal requirements .

CARDINAL . The procedure begins before ORG which " acts either on its own initiative , or at the request of ORG , the Minister responsible for public health , the procureur du Roi or the medical commission , or on complaint by a medical practitioner or CARDINAL party " ( LAW . CARDINAL , first sub - paragraph , of LAW no . CARDINAL ) . The procedure continues before ORG if it has been seised either by the practitioner concerned , or by ORG assessor , or by the President of ORG acting jointly with CARDINAL of the Vice - Presidents ; an appeal has suspensive effect ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Investigation of the matter necessarily involves the participation of a member of the judiciary : before ORG , for the purposes of the initial investigation , this will be the assessor ; before ORG , for the purposes , if need be , of a supplementary investigation , it will be the ORG member acting as rapporteur ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL above ) . Furthermore , the ORG member who acted as rapporteur may always be heard by ORG CARDINAL par . CARDINAL , CARDINAL par . CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Royal Decree no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Before ORG , the proceedings are conducted in private ( LAW . CARDINAL , sub - paragraph CARDINAL , of LAW no . CARDINAL and LAW of DATE ) . The medical practitioner concerned has the right to be informed as soon as possible of the opening of an inquiry against him ( LAW of DATE ) ; the procedure further provides for time - limits and formalities allowing him to have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence ( Articles CARDINAL and DATE ) ; in addition , it contains guarantees concerning the use of languages ( Articles DATE to CARDINAL ) .

The practitioner is also entitled to challenge the members of the organ hearing his case ; he appears in person and may be assisted by CARDINAL or more counsel who , like himself , may inspect the case - file ( Articles CARDINAL , DATE and CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG are bound to deliver their ruling within a reasonable time , to preserve the secrecy of their deliberations and to give reasons for their decision . The person concerned must be promptly informed of the decision and of any appeal which may have been entered . Decisions are taken by simple majority . However , CARDINAL majority is required for striking a practitioner off the register of the ORG or for his suspension for DATE . The same rule applies to ORG decisions ordering a sanction where ORG has imposed none or increasing the severity of the sanction imposed by ORG ( Article CARDINAL in fine of LAW no . CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL of LAW of DATE ) . The sanctions which may be imposed by ORG - and also , if appropriate , ORG - are " warning , censure , reprimand , suspension of the right to practise medicine for a period not exceeding DATE and striking off the register of ORG ( LAW no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Under LAW no . DATE , " final decisions of ORG or ORG may be referred to ORG either by the Minister responsible for public health , or by the President of ORG acting jointly with CARDINAL of the Vice - Presidents , or by the practitioner concerned , on the ground of contravention of the law " - the latter term being understood in a wide sense - " or of non - observance of a formal requirement which is either a matter of substance or laid down on pain of nullity " . ORG will have before it the complete case - file ( decisions at first instance and on appeal , memorials and final submissions of the parties , including a detailed statement of the facts ) ; however , it can not verify the findings of fact made by ORG , unless it is alleged that there has been a breach of the rules of evidence . ORG does not have jurisdiction to rectify factual errors on the part of ORG or to examine whether the sanction is proportionate to the fault .
An appeal to ORG on a point of law has suspensive effect .

CARDINAL . Decisions in a disciplinary matter which have become final are notified to the Minister of ORG ; the most important ones ( striking off the register of the ORG or suspension of the right to practise ) are also notified to the medical commission and to the procureur général attached to ORG ( LAW no . CARDINAL and LAW of DATE ) .
